ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

PHASING OUT OF PIG FARMS


    1. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for the Environment, in view of the Government's pronouncements to phase out pig farming altogether, what steps are being considered to compensate adequately the medium-sized pig farmers who were encouraged by the Primary Production Department to extend their farms and others who were encouraged to set up pig farms on a commercial scale.

     The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Communications and Information and the Minister for the Environment (Dr Lee Boon Yang) (for the Minister for the Environment): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am answering on behalf of my Minister,

    Sir, following the decision to phase out pig farming in Singapore, a decision which was made while the Primary Production Department was under the charge of the former First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education, the Primary Production Department has been transferred to my Ministry.

    Since the transfer, which was effective on 2nd January 1985, my Ministry has set to work to prepare an implementation plan to phase out pig farms in Singapore. I would like to assure the hon. Member for Punggol that phasing out will be done in stages. We will also take into account the timing, availability of an alternative supply of pork and resenlement of affected farmers in order to minimize hardship to these farmers. The details will be announced shortly to hon. Members with the distinction of having pigs in their constituency.

     Mr Heng Chiang Meng (Jalan Kayu): Sir, may I ask the Parliamentary Secretary whether these details will also include the pig farmers on TOL presently in my constiuency, and also whether, although they are on TOL, the compensation that may be given to them could be accelerated because sooner or later these people will have to be actually resettled?

Column: 362



     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have just informed the House, in reply to the question from the Member for Punggol, that the Ministry is working out an implementation plan. I would like to assure the Member for Jalan Kayu that his pig farming constituents will also be given due consideration in this implementation plan. We will take into consideration any request for resettlement and compensation by pig farmers who wish to voluntarily cease pig farming if the land is required for other public projects.

    Since I am on my feet, Mr Speaker, Sir, may I be allowed, in anticipation, to say to the hon. Member for Chua Chu Kang, who is not in this House at the present moment, that his constituency will also be one of the constituencies where there are groups of farmers that we will consider in our implementation plan.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I ask the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Communications and Information and the Minister for the Environment, how long it will take his Ministry, ie, the Ministry of the Environment, to consider this implementation plan; when will this plan be implemented, and whether he is aware that the answer he has given does not explicitly cover the main question that I posed?

     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, my Ministry, as I have said, is still considering various options that are available to us in the phasing out of pig farms in Singapore. We expect to be able to come to a conclusion very soon and we will make an announcement, as I mentioned earlier, in particular, to the three Members who have pig farmers among their constituents.

    The question of compensation that was raised by the Member will be part of the overall solution to this problem, a solution that we will provide to all farmers who are affected by this phasing-out programme.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: Mr Speaker, Sir, may I further ask, in relation to this problem, whether the Parliamentary Secretary is aware that compensation to the pig farmers - if it is not relevant, Sir, I may be out of order - who have tried to comply with the policy of installing pig waste treatment plants has not been adequate?

Column: 363



     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, the policy of encouraging pig farmers to set up waste treatment plants was rescinded sometime last year, and since then farmers who had embarked on such a programme and had incurred expenses were invited to submit their claims for a reimbursement of those expenses. This Ministry is still in the final stages of coming to an agreement with a small number of farmers who have not accepted in full the offer of payment by our Ministry. I would like to say that, overall, more than 90% of the farmers who have incurred such expenses have already come to an agreement with our Ministry with regard to the quantum of compensation for the cost that they have incurred.

     Mr Heng Chiang Meng rose ---

     Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not have any pig farmers in my constituency but may I ask a supplementary question. I am sorry. You have the Floor.

     Mr Heng Chiang Meng: Mr Speaker, Sir, may I ask if the Ministry, in considering the compensation for the pig farmers, will also consider in their plans those who want to voluntarily give up their farming activities, although the Government may not require their land for any form of clearance at this stage?

     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, many of the pig farmers are operating their farms on Temporary Occupation Licences (TOL). If their farms are occupying lands that are required for other development purposes, they will be resenled and they will be paid an ex gratia payment. For those who at this present moment so decide by themselves that they want to voluntarily quit pig farming and since the Government does not have an immediate need for that piece of land, I think there is no particular reason to offer compensation. But if this phasing-out of pig farming is carried out because, as I said, of other public development projects, then of course there will be compensation paid.

     Mr Jeyaretnam rose ---

     Mr Speaker: Have you got pig farming in your constituency, Mr Jeyaretnam?

Column: 364



     Mr Jeyaretnam: No, I do not have, Mr Speaker, Sir. I said that, but may I be allowed to ask a supplementary question?

     Mr Speaker: All right.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: It is regarding the compensation that is paid to these farmers on account of their investment on waste treatment plant. I understood from the Parliamentary Secretary that 90% had accepted this. May I know whether they have been paid in full, the loss that they have suffered as a result of this investment, or are they only being paid a partial amount?

     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Anson has a habit of smelling a rat when there is not any around. He has a suspicious turn of mind. What I said earlier on was that the Government has come to an agreement with 90% of the farmers who had incurred expenses as a result of the programme to require them to set up waste treatment plants. All these expenses have been documented and the Committee has reviewed all the claims to the expenses, and where each and every expense is justified it has been reimbursed in full.

Column: 364

PUNGGOL/TAMPINES AREA
(Fly menace)


    2. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for the Environment if he is aware of the sudden increase of flies in the Punggol/ Tampines area, particularly around the Chinese New Year season; what were the causes and what measures have been taken to eradicate this menace and whether the situation is under control.

     The Minister for the Environment (Dr Ahmad Mattar): Mr Speaker, Sir, my Ministry is aware of an increase in the incidence of fly breedings at the Lorong Halus Dumping Ground around the Chinese New Year period. This increase was due to increased refuse dumped at the dumping grounds and a temporary shortage of earth to cover the refuse, The fly situation at the Lorong Halus Dumping Ground, Sir, is monitored daily and the increase was controlled by insecticidal spray.

    Sir, during a routine survey of the Hougang housing estate by my health

Column: 365

inspectors, we also detected a number of fly breedings at the refuse chutes of some of the flats and bin centres. This problem arose because of an increase in refuse output in the estate due to the Chinese New Year period as well as the durian season. The fly breedings were destroyed and the situation is back to normal. The fly nuisance at Hougang housing estate was not related to the increase in incidence of fly breedings at Lorong Halus Dumping Ground, which is about 2 km away.

    Sir, at this stage, I would like to mention to this House that as long as we have to dump our refuse we can anticipate complaints of this nature to arise once in a while, especially during festive seasons and during prolonged periods of bad weather.

    The other point that I feel I should make in this House is that sewerage, refuse disposal and street cleansing activities are labour-intensive. In spite of automation and mechanization, we still need to depend on a large number of daily-rated employees, or what we call the DREs. I think we are fortunate, Sir, that we do have these people to do the job. But I am afraid, Sir, it would not be for long. The DREs belong to a special breed of people, and one major problem faced by my Ministry in this area is the declining number of our DRE workforce. Retirement and resignation, Sir, could not be matched by recruitment which is increasingly difficult because of the obnoxious nature of the job. But be rest assured, Sir, that my Ministry, particularly the Environmental Health Officers of my Ministry, are vigilant. They are always on the alert and they will attend to complaints of this nature immediately and in the best way they know how.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: Mr Speaker, Sir, may I ask the Hon. Minister for the Enyironment two supplementary questions: one in relation to labour and the other in relation to disposal of refuse?

    With regard to the question of labour, would he enlighten this House as to how his Ministry intends to overcome such a problem, and whether they are overcoming this problem by the construction of another incinerator plant which will eliminate more labour and be able to

Column: 366

dispose more refuse? In this respect, we have to bear in mind that another part of the land in Punggol has been acquired for the purpose of trade refuse disposal.

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: Mr Speaker, Sir, for land-scarce Singapore, the most cost-effective method of refuse waste disposal is by incineration, particularly because of the high volume-reduction achieved in transforming refuse to ash. The heat generated from the combustion of refuse can be made use of to generate electricity and the ferrous metals present in the ash residue can be extracted and sold as scrap iron.

    As you know, Sir, we have at the moment one refuse incineration plant at Ulu Pandan and the Government is currently building a second one at Tuas. Based on the projected tonnage of volume that we can anticipate in the 1990s, we may have to build a third one. But even if we build all the incineration plants that we need to build, the level of technology today, Sir, can only allow 80% of the total refuse collected to be incinerated. The remaining 20%, what we call the non-incinerables, will still have to be dumped.

    On the question of acquisition of land in Punggol for dumping, I think that part of the Punggol has been earmarked for the development of a new town and, therefore, the site for the additional dumping ground has been transferred to a new area which is adjacent to the Lorong Halus dumping ground.

Column: 366

RESETTLEMENT OF STREET HAWKERS


    3. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for the Environment how many street hawkers have been resettled into the hawker centres since the introduction Qf the policy to ensure better and more hygienic handling of food; how many more will have to be resited and when will this exercise be completed and, whether there are plar)s to build (nore hawker centres, partrcularly for the selling of cooked food, in the light of changing eating habits.

     Dr Lee Boon Yang (for the Minister for the Environment): Sir, in May 1971, the Government decided to build markets and

Column: 367

food centres to accommodate all the street hawkers. There were then about 17,800 hawkers on the streets.

    Today, some 17,300 of these hawkers have been relocated into markets and food centres. There are now only 546 street hawkers. They will be housed by the end of this year, or early next year, in suitable food centres.

    There are a total of 25,448 food and market produce stalls housed mainly in centres managed by HDB, MOE, and other statutory boards. 1,525 of the market produce stalls are housed in 14 private markets.

    Sir, the Ministry of the Environment has no plans to build any more food centres, as the relocation programme is nearing completion. We have barely over 500 more hawkers to be resettled. The HDB has indicated that they will not build any more food centres or wet markets in their new housing estates. Instead, they will build supermarkets. They will provide appropriate shopping places for people to operate mini-markets, neighbourhood shops, specialty shops, and eating establishments such as coffee shops, fast food outlets and other food retail outlets.

    Sir, Singaporeans have a wide variety of food outlets to suit their taste and budget. There are 192 food centres with some 9,069 foodstalls, 1,508 eating houses with a total of 8,805 food stalls. Over and above these stalls, there are still numerous other snack bars, fast food outlets, restaurants spread out all over the island.

    Apart from those provided by HDB as part of its amenities for housing estates, the private sectors can also set up food centres and eating establishments to cater for the demand of the residents and the working population.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: Mr Speaker, Sir, does the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Communications and Information and the Minister for the Environment not realize that the answer, as given to this House, means that the Government is unwittingly encouraging our people to eat outside their homes, and thereby do away

Column: 368

with the need to cook their food at home, bearing in mind the question of the imponderable when food has to be stacked in the house and, if it need be, to be cooked in the home?

     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government, in particular my Ministry, is aware that more and more people are eating outside their home. This has to be so, as we encourage more and more of our women to leave the home to join the workforce. It is part of the change in our lifestyle. And, as I said in my answer, HDB, in its development of new towns where more than 80% of our population will be living in the future, will build alternative forms of food outlets, a different style from what we formerly associate with our cheap hawker centre. It will be a proper eating establishment incorporating good standards of hygiene in the food preparation areas, clean environment for the tired working people to relax in and to have their meals, congenial surroundings for them to have their cup of coffee. With all these steps being taken, I think the problem of people eating outside their home will not exist.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: Mr Speaker, Sir, just one final supplementary question. Does not the Parliamentary Secretary agree with me that all this means additional expenditure, resulting in having less for savings?

     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, there may be some increase in costs but the quality of service is increased to justify this increase in cost. The more important thing is that this Government continues to provide full employment, continues to manage the economy such that people have good employment, and they receive salaries that are commensurate with their skills, so that they are able to afford this marginal increase for better quality services. Overall, Sir, this is our objective. We want to raise the standard of living of all Singaporeans. We want to give them the means to afford a better quality of life.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, may I ask a supplementary question, although not on food and hawker centres? Did I understand the Parliamentary Secretary to say that his Ministry was discontinuing the buildin of wet markets in new estates? If

Column: 369

that is so, may I ask whether a survey has been taken from the residents as to their preference?

     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Anson has been in this House longer than 1. He was in this House on 14 March 1984 when my predecessor, the hon. Member for Changi, informed this House and, of course, the Member for Anson too, and here, Mr Speaker, Sir, allow me to quote:

    'In 1981, a study team chaired by the former Senior Parliamentary Secretary of my Ministry and comprising Members of Parliament and officials from the Ministry of the Environment, Primary Production Department, HDB and the Ministry of Trade and Industry, was set up to review the existing retail distribution system. In their reivew, the study team recommended that wet markets be replaced by supermarkets, specialty and neighbourhood stores. My Ministry has not built wet markets for many years and HDB has also stopped building wet markets in their new housing estates. It has also been decided that no more new food centres will be built in the future by the Ministry of the Environment or the HDB.' [Hansard, cols. 995 - 996]

     Mr Jeyaretnam: I am afraid the Parliamentary Secretary has not answered my question, The question is, "Was a survey taken from the residents?" I know you read out the recommendation of this Committee. The question is, "Did the Committee take a survey from the residents?"

     The Minister for Home Affairs and Second Minister for Law (Prof S. Jayakumar): On a point of order, Mr Speaker, Sir. Ought not the Member for Anson ask this question at the time the previous statement was made?

     Mr Jeyaretnam: May I not ask the question now? May I know?

     The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Community Development (Mr S. Dhanabalan): Mr Speaker, Sir, on a point of order. It is not relevant to the original question that was asked in the Order Paper.

     Mr Speaker: He said this question is not relevant to the question on the Order Paper.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: But we are talking about the policy of the Ministry of the Environment.

     Mr Speaker: I allow you to carry on. Now you can carry on.

Column: 370



     Mr Jeyaretnam: Thank you, Sir. Would the Parliamentary Secretary answer this question?

     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Committee in 1981 made a thorough assessment of all forms of retail - food retail, cooked food retail, market produce retail, and after exhaustive investigation came to the conclusion that wet markets would no longer be the most efficient and effective means of distributing or retail"ng our food in Singapore in the context of a modern Singapore.

    The other point that I want to remind the Member for Anson is that a wet market entails a high cost in terms of manpower. A very large number of people is required to man these very few stalls in the perspective of the number of hours that they actually operate. And the alternative offered by the HDB which is responsible for building all the new towns is a far better solution for the residents. The supermarkets and the mini-markets operate for much longer hours of shopping for the convenience of the residents. If our residents are to have food, fresh good quality food available to them at their convenience in a mini-market or a supermarket which opens from 9.30 in the morning to 9.30 in the evening must represent a tremendous improvement of service. It also makes it so much easier for all the working mothers, the working women, on their way home, to just purchase what they need and go home and cook for the family; rather than rush out early in the morning to do their shopping in a wet market which is congested, wet, as he says, and very often very crowded.

    The other point, Mr Speaker, Sir, which I would like to remind the Member for Anson is that we have in the past built many wet markets, and at the present moment many of these markets have large numbers of vacant stalls. Many of the stalls are unoccupied. Many of the people who have taken up the stalls have discontinued their business. Is that not in itself, Sir, indicative that our lifestyle in Singapore is changing to the point where people are more comfortable, more willing and better prepared to use the facilities offered by the mini-markets and supermarkets with their extended hours of shopping?

Column: 371



     Mr Jeyaretnam: You still have not answered my question.

PRESIDENT'S ADDRESS

Debate on the Address
(Fifth Allotted Day)


    Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question (1st March, 1985),

    'That the following Address in reply to the Speech of the President be agreed to:-

    'We, the Parliament of the Republic of Singapore, express our thanks to the President for the Speech which he delivered on behalf of the Government at the Opening of the First Session of this Parliament.".' -[Dr Tan Cheng Bock].

    Question again proposed.
11.36 am

     Encik Yatiman Yusof (Kampong Kembangan)( In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to support the motion of thanks to the President moved by the Member for Ayer Rajah.

    Sir, the President's speech and the Addenda to the speech clearly put on record the objectives that can be achieved by this Government. The goals are high, noble and meaningful. They are meant not only to maintain what we have achieved but also to improve upon it. More importantly, it spells out the Government's intention to give special attention to the less fortunate - the 15-20% in the lower rungs of our social ladder.

    To me, the President's speech and the Addenda are important for three reasons. Firstly, they give a vision of the pattern of society; the tempo of life that Singapore will be undergoing, with its own rhythm, in 15 to 25 years' time.

    Secondly, they reflect the Government's determination to raise the standard of living of the people through improvements in the physical and social infrastructure so that a mature, upright, strong and cohesive society will emerge that will be able to march forward with confidence towards the year 2000 and beyond. At the same time, the society, Mr Speaker, Sir, will be aware of its capabilities.

    Thirdly, they clearly draw up the course of action to be taken to turn what we regard as a dream into a reality for the next generation.

Column: 373



    Mr Speaker, Sir, allow me to comment on the course of action that has been drawn up and stress the need for mental and attitudinal preparations to be made, so that there will be the correct anitude and mentality, before the longer-term programme is implemented.

    We have set out our goals. They are very high, but they are not impossible to achieve. With determined and courageous leaders, bold in making decisions and responsible in making changes and modifications, that dream will become a reality.

    The President's speech, inter alia, touched on our desire to form what is called the Singapore character that the people want and to attract the young, who will be responsible for the nation in the future, into being involved in the process of development.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, allow me to put those aspirations in their proper perspective by briefly outlining our history, current issues and future challenges so that we would be able to align the action taken to the situation that will arise at that time; because if we want to give substance to our development efforts, we must realize our limitations in the future.

    Sir, the era of do-or-die struggles in facing crisis after crisis to determine whether we would float and survive as a political entity here or sink in the violent turmoil of history that would leave us severely shattered, the era of a cancerous nation beset with the problems of unemployment that led to communal strife and riots or a nation at peace, the era of a political entity beset with poverty and haunted by a crippled economy in which the people live in squalor shackled by unemployment or one with the people having a proper roof over their heads for shelter, good food, clothing and education, have passed.

    With firm, farsighted and resolute leadership and endowed with a strategic location, a rather stable regional political situation, we have built up Singapore from the ashes of disunity and the threat of destruction into what we see today.

Column: 374



    Now, problems pertaining to employment, education, accommodation, food and clothing, which are our basic daily necessities, have been overcome. And we are now preparing to face new challenges and shoulder new responsibilities.

    Continuity in political leadership has been prepared for and with the emergence of a new echelon of leaders who are ready to shoulder new responsibilities, this process will go on. The process of transfer of leadership has begun and we can no longer look back or take a step backwards.

    The foundation for continued economic growth and development towards a higher level, in the form of such infrastructure as roads, wharves, buildings, a modern communications system and a financial and information centre, has been laid.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Ayer Rajah who moved this motion is a Member who is well-known for his critical attitude and frankness. He has chosen the analogy of the kidney transplant. The Member for Teck Ghee has chosen the bus as an analogy and other Members have used many other analogies. For instance, the Member for Kaki Bukit has used the analogy of a soccer team. The Member for Bukit Merah, who is not here today, Mr Speaker, Sir, chose the analogy of the bicycle to describe Singapore. It seems that I cannot avoid using an analogy myself and I would like to choose the analogy of the ship, and I call that ship, the Ship of Singapore - not TS Singapura - but the ship, Singapura.
